fields.description:
When creating a LIC file, if one doesn't have the correct format of the LIC file, the following error is seen in the cloud-output.log:

{code}
....
due to com.eucalyptus.auth.LicParseException: Syntax error in configuration
{code}

This confused users, especially if there is a compound search filter thats part of the _accounting-groups_, _groups_, and/or _users_ element(s).

This is a request for a tool that will check the format of the LIC file before using _euca-modify-property_ to enabled LDAP/AD sync.
fields.summary: LDAP Sync: Tool to Confirm Correct Format of LIC File

comments.body: It looks like the reported error is due to a JSON syntax issue, not related to the content of the filter.

Hey [~tjcramer],

Haven't been able to confirm yet.  I tested out the following LIC setup on Eucalyptus 3.3:

{code}
{


  "ldap-service":{


    "server-url":"ldap:<IP ADDRESS>:389",
    "auth-method":"simple",
    "user-auth-method":"simple",
    "auth-principal":"cn=Directory Manager,dc=stankonia,dc=com",
    "auth-credentials":"<PASSWORD>",
    "use-ssl":"false",
    "ignore-ssl-cert-validation":"false",
    "krb5-conf":"/etc/krb5.conf",
  },

  "sync":{

    "enable":"true",
    "auto":"true",
    "interval":"900000",
    "clean-deletion":"true",

"user393", "user394", "user395", "user396", "user397", "user398", "user399", "user400", "user401", "user402", "user403", "user404", "user405", "user406", "user407", "user408", "user409", "user410", "user411", "user412", "user413", "user414", "user415", "user416", "user417", "user418", "user419", "user420", "user421", "user422", "user423", "user424", "user425", "user426", "user427", "user428", "user429", "user430", "user431", "user432", "user433", "user434", "user435", "user436", "user437", "user438", "user439", "user440", "user451", "user452", "user453", "user454", "user455", "user456", "user457", "user458", "user459", "user460", "user461", "user462", "user463", "user464", "user465", "user466", "user467", "user468", "user469", "user470", "user471", "user472", "user473", "user474", "user475", "user476", "user477", "user478", "user479", "user480", "user481", "user482", "user483", "user484", "user485", "user486", "user487", "user488", "user489", "user490", "user491", "user492", "user493", "user494", "user495", "user496", "user497", "user498", "user499", "user500", "major-groupone"],
  },

  "groups":{

    "base-dn":"ou=groups,dc=msjackson,dc=stankonia,dc=com",
    "id-attribute":"cn",
    "member-attribute":"memberUid",
    "selection":{

        "filter":"(&(objectClass=posixGroup)(gidNumber=*))",
        "not-select":["cn=allusers,ou=groups,dc=msjackson,dc=stankonia,dc=com"],
    }
  },

  "users":{

    "base-dn":"ou=people,dc=msjackson,dc=stankonia,dc=com",
    "id-attribute":"uid",
    "sasl-id-attribute":"uid",
    "user-info-attributes":{
        "displayName":"Full Name",
        "title":"Title",
        "mail":"Email"
    },
    "selection":{

        "filter":"(&(objectClass=inetOrgPerson)(objectClass=posixAccount)(mail=*))",
    }
  },
}
{code}

The only issue I am running into is EUCA-5876.  

This *may* have been more of a end-user (i.e.community user) issue.  The reason I say this is because when I *did* have the error show up:

{code}
Thu Apr 18 12:01:57 2013 ERROR [LicParser:New I/O server worker #2-45] [com.eucalyptus.auth.Debugging.logError(Debugging.java):111] net.sf.json.JSONException: Unterminated string at character 8068 of {
	at com.eucalyptus.auth.ldap.LicParser.parse(LicParser.java:118)
Thu Apr 18 12:01:57 2013 ERROR [AuthenticationProperties:New I/O server worker #2-45] [com.eucalyptus.auth.AuthenticationProperties$LicChangeListener.fireChange(AuthenticationProperties.java):96] com.eucalyptus.auth.LicParseException: Syntax error in configuration
com.eucalyptus.auth.LicParseException: Syntax error in configuration
	at com.eucalyptus.auth.ldap.LicParser.parse(LicParser.java:130)
	at com.eucalyptus.auth.ldap.LicParser.parse(LicParser.java:118)
{code}

It told me the exact line where the error was located.  This error is different than what was [seen previously|https://engage.eucalyptus.com/customer/en/portal/questions/890351-active-directory-integration].  Do we know if there was a change in the JSON lib we used in 3.2.1?  Based upon my testing, it looks like this should be turned into a feature request to create a tool to do a pre-check to make sure the file is in the correct format.  Thoughts?
Tools that accept JSON could be updated to perform syntax validation. It seems better to ensure the server error messages are good as then all tools benefit (mainly thinking of IAM policies)
So the actual customer issue has a workaround.  This is about having better error messages with bad JSON
